doc.field: <description type="note">Preliminaries and editorial matter omitted<lb/>The following plays have been taken from this source:</description>

This Show was written & prepared to be acted in Anno 1640. The Drift or Plot to Shew ye Insatiat desires yt posess ye Mind & Make it Search after Nouelties euen to Impossebilety— Dorado Nubecula Maior ANTARCTICUS A Scene of Hills & Craggy Rocks All couered wt h Snowe A Vnicorns Horne Terra Australis Incognita A Princes Sitting vpon a Throne on eyther Side of which a Phenix. Psittacorum Regio Terra del Foco Six yong ladies Six yong Gallants in Various Couters whiffing Tobacco.

A draweinge Traverse waued like the Sea & some sharpe heads of Rockes Peepeing through the waues. ffrom the opposite syde enters first a Sea Fareinge Man In a Rugg'd gowne and a hood holdinge a Gloabe Terrestiall In one hand, and A Sphære in the other; on which whilest hee would seeme to reade or discourse he turnes them both round. Then Startles first at ye Scene whence he discouers Smoak—next at Six boyes who represent Porposes & come tumbling out of it—Then Enters Oceanus (gray head & beard) in a Loose Mantle of Sea-Greene embroydred here and there with silver Oas waue Like—whoe enraged att the Seamans bold attempts strikes the ground or Stage thrice with his Trident which beinge Couered too in Representation of the Sea with Cloath painted waue-Like It sends from under it two Tritons who with their shell Trumpetts awaken the foure Windes (viz:) the Lowde Musicke—A Hautboy, a Cornett, a Sagbutt and a double Curtault, which Tempest rais'd the Skyper strikes Saile and departs. And Oceanus then retireinge to a Seate Cutt in a Rocke of Purpose for him ouer which was written (Raguallio d'Oceano) Hee Calls for Pontus, Fretum, and Synus, his three Sonns, giues them with his blessinge their seuerall Charges Fretum enters first habbitted in Changeable Taffatey embroydred with Rockes in Siluer Oas and with Ilands Sending forth flames exprest in Goulden Oas, A Crowne Imperiall on his head Betweene A Myter and A Croyssant or halfe Moone. Ouer the Doore he Comes out att Gibraltar written in great Then Pontus out of the same doore Clad in blacke watered Tabby, A white Turbant on his head and a Cymiter by his Syde. Synus enters out of Another doore ouer which written in great Bazora—His Garment gould Tinsell and flowred Indian worke, on his head a Persyan Turbant Whose speeches ended they fall into an Anticke high rough daunce Blowne by the foure Windes or Lowde Musicke, The Trytons encreaseinge their Number to fiue helpe to make the ffiggure and soe they ebb out.

Heer Enters a Nayd or Water Nimph to implore leau for Cristallina her Queen to present her Self to Ocean: Then enters Cristallina Goddesse of the fresher streams All in Siluer Tinsell, a Chaplett or garland of Meadowflowers on her head, her haire disheuill'd and Loose. Damanndinge Audience of Oceanus for the Ambassadours or Riuers were Ebbinge from the Isles and Terra firma uppon this Negotiation of discouery of ye fiu't part of ye world which Grannted—there Enter ffrom Queene Europa—Sixe— Tamesis, Rhenus, togeather out of third doore Ligeris, Tagus out of ye same but one a while after th'other Tybris, Alpheus togeather out of Gibraltar. ffrom Queene Asia—three— Indus, Ganges, out of the third doore Euphrates—out of Bazora. ffrom Queene Affrica—two— Nilus—out of Gibraltar Niger—out of the third doore ffrom Queene America three— Orenoke, out of the 3d: doore. Parana, out of the 3d: doore. Maragnon, out of the 3d: doore. Each of which Queenes Negotiatinge by theise Ministers of their State to procure Leaue for those seuerall Countryes through which they runn and from whence they Came to Aduenture Plantation through his Meanes where they heard as yet there was none (vizt) in Terra Austral: Incognita ffor want of through discouerye: And haveinge obtaind permission for them to trye their ffortunes depart ioyfully and well pleased in a daunce played out by a sett of Recorders the stillest of winde Instruments. Cristallina all this while sittinge uppon a Banke of Mosse prankes her selfe in a Lookeinge glasse hung att her Girdle. These gone out Oceanus discouers to the Trytons (whoe were reentred to attend him) his purpose of delusion, which done and all becalm'd—The Seaman enters with A Carde and Compasse in one hand and a Iacob-staffe or else a Quadrant in the other and speakes—wc h ended Europe sendes for discouery An English A French: A Duch: An Italian A Greeke A Spaniard Asia— An Indian A Persian A Turke Affrica— An Egiptian or Gypsye An Abissine or Black Moor. America— A Guianian An Amazon A Brazilian These by the Musickes Charme falling into seuerall daunces and speeches as they Come out seuerally Awaken Oceanusses promise presenting him Likewise with the Bounty of each Nation—the which he Committs in Charge to the Trytons to keepe—Then Biddinge them Blowe: The Scæne By degrees opens and discouers the Throne to each of them, But shutts againe, and soe hee rouseinge himselfe upp and puttinge on a rigid sterne Countenance Strykes the waue-Like stage with his Trident, att which the 4 Windes sound an enchanntinge ayer to which they goe dauncinge out as wise as they Came in; the Pilott or Seaman filling upp the ffigure This ended Oceanus inuoakes Aryon whoe Enters rideinge uppon a Dolphin ffish trapt with fflouer-deluces. His habitt a Blew silke Mantle, a wreath of Lawrell on his head, playing on a harpe Studded with Starrs. Att which Musick as he aduances into the Midle of the roome The Trauerse opens againe and Scæne appeares att Large; ffrom under which as out of a Caue or Hell Orpheus issues In a greene Taffatay weede and a Lawrell garland too: A harpe in his hand on which he ioynes in harmonye And Ayer with Aryon, Being followed by two Like Beastes, two Like Rockes of Stone, and two Like Trees whome after an Antique Daunce he Licences in two wordes to depart—Then raysing their Ayer to a higher Key they play a Solemne Maskinge daunce att which the Princes descends but uery slowly and presenting her selfe in great humilitye att Oceanusses ffeett. expresses in a fewe wordes her thankes to him in preseruinge her Chastitye from the violence of that attempted Inuasion, and soe deuotes her selfe eternally his Tributary. whoe most willingly accepting of her for his Consort and Princes, Commaunds the Trytons to Sound thrice and soe proclaime the future Nuptialls to be Speedily perfourmed (Dureinge which Proclamation Aryon and Orpheus cease) Now for Conclusion to this Solemnitye of Mirth and ioye the sixe Younge Men take out the sixe Young Ladyes All which attended the Princesse out of the Scæne and fall into the Masking daunce which Aryon and Orpheus playe whilest Oceanus sends abroad the Escutchions to the best of ye Behoulders as fauours and rewardes of their patiences This done he returnes with the Princesse and her traine upp into the Scæne, which drawne Closse they appeare noe more but a Chorus of Mearmen and Mear-Maydes to the number of Sixe or Eyght Come forth and Conclude all in an Epilogue.

Morall: How each Countrey is habbitted Togeather with their Emblemmaticall Scutchons. Europe— English —In a slasht french doublett, Great Band, strayght Spanish hose, duch felt hatt, short Italian Cloake, Long black Gretian haire—In Scutchion a Shepheard Swaine asleepe Whilest his flockes are feeding about him representing Security with this word— ffœlices Nimium Bona si sua Norint French: —In Querpo unbuttoned and untruss'd, Long hose with Points, Great Bootes and spurrs, rugg'd hatt and feather, A Locke, A Great ffalling Band or else Pickadille, In Scutchion a feather wau'd with the winde with this word— Mouemur vento Duch: In a Great Bellyed fustian doublett with Mettall Buttons, A paire of Skippers hose Loose att knee, A Little pinch't round Robbin Band starcht uery Blewe, Noe Cuffes, his hands in his pocketts, A high narrow Crown'd hatt with Brimms Suteable, And a Cypres torse for Band, Mustachioes yow would thinke might reach to either Pole they had out-Growne his eares though the haire of his round head was shorter—In sheild he Beares a Cabbage Leafe, A Turnipp And a Bunch of Carretts with this word. Corruptio vnius est generatio alterius. Italian —In a Cassock and hose, plaine black high Narrow Crownd hatt broad Brimm'd, a Little Band, playeing uppon a Gittar under his short Cloake— In Scutchion on pistolling another att his Backe with this— Morte Nihil Certius. Gretian —In a long black Philosophers thred bare Gowne, Noe Band att all, uery Long blacke haire, Beares in Scutchion Athens reuers't, And Melpomene sitting by Lamenting for all the other sisters whoe now are drownd Not in Oceano But in Otio, wherefore this word serues— Otium Ingenij Rubigo Spaniard —In a Great Sett Ruffe starcht Blewe; doublett with a Cropp And sleeues with pocketts, strayght hose, high Narrow Crownd hatt with Broad Brimms, a Long Cloake with round Cape, a Long spitt Rapier, in sheild the Gloabe of the earth with this— Paucis Contentus Asia: Indian —In a Light thinne skarlett Coulour'd Iacckett, his Armes and thyes Naked and Black as Iett, Braceletts of Pearle and eare Iewells of Pearle—In one hand a dart headed with a ffish bone, in the other A Conoöe in a Scutchion with this worde— ffrustra Lauamur aquis Persian —In a Light watchett Coat to the Ancles girt about him with a white Skarffe, A Cemiter by his syde —A pyde Turbant, in Scutchion the Picture of Mydas with this word O quam sapientius optes. Turke —In a Crimson weed to the Midd Legg—A white Turbant, A Cemiter drawne in one hand, in the other a Croissant or halfe Moone in a Targett with this worde. Cresco ut diminuam Affrica— Egiptian —Swarty in A Tawney Iunk, A Capp of Snake skinns on his head, houlding in Scutchion the ffiggure of Memphis inuyron'd with Pyramids with this word— Crescit post funera virtus. A Wilde Arab: In A Mantle of Pladd of diuers Coulours, his Armes and Thyes bare, Complexion Moore, A Linnen Cloth on his head hanging downe behinde, holding A Iauelin in one hande and A sheild with A Lyons head drawne bleeding in the other with this word— Immites hasta Capescit America: Guianian A Tawney Moore, A Skarfe of white Athwart his Midle girt by Bases of seuerall Couloured feathers and a Cap suteable, A sheafe of Arrowes att his Backe, A Bowe in one hand, Sheild in the other, with Mountaines drawne in it, and this word— Thesaurum Conditum sibi Scutum. Amazon: A Woaman with but one breast, her Bases purple Taffatey and Mantle suitable, An Arrow att her syde, bow in hand, A Scutchion in the other, wherein drawne a Whole quiuer of Arrowes with this word Addit Concordia vires. Brasilian In Mantle and Bases of Redd, an Arrow Bloody att his syde, a bowe in his hand, a sheild in the other wherein the picture of one man eateing and deuouring another and this word In se Natura Luxuriosa ruit

How each Riuer should be habbitted and what there presents. Europe. Tamesis In A coate of Swanns downe, prsents a fleece of woole. Rhenus —In A Coate of Vine Leaues, prsents a Romakin of wine. Ligeris —In a Coate of Mullberry Leaues: prsents seuerall Bunches of Red grapes Tagus —In A gold yellow Taffatey Cassock: prsents Oranges, Lemmonds & Granadoes Tibris —In a ffryer Minims habbitt or Min Bonshommes, prsents him with Sodom Apples which are faire to Looke on, but when toucht fall to Ashes. Alpheus —In a Comitragicall weed, a Buskin on one Legg, a Sock on the other foote, A Lawrell on his head, presents him with a paper of old Verses Soe effaced in their Characters as Skearce to be read Asya: Indus —In A Mantle of silke spunn from Leaues, prsents diuerse sorts of spices Ganges —In the Like, presents sweete woodes, Ostredge feathers & Ellephants tooth Euphrates —In A Persian dresse, presents him with rare workes &c. Affrica. Nilus —In a Phantasticke dresse of Crocadile Skinns, A Capp Like a Piramide, Nyne Armes from which he presents seuerall strange Creatures ingendred of Mudd. Niger —A Moore couered onely from the waste downeward, prsents a Ginny Bird and Some wheat. America. Orenoke —In a Closse Iumpe under which some Gold Tinsell discouered—presents a Rowle of Tobacco. Parana: —In the Like, presents a handfull of Gold Oare Maragnon —In the Like, presents a parcell of Beauer Skinns.

The first Entry The Seaman enters and speakes Great Ptolome, the Morneings Glimering Light to our Deepe Misterye, be the Starre to Steere my Course by; Whilest I seeke to turne the round The Globe uppon my ffingers end, and Leaue noe part for ffuture tymes discouery: With the Sunne,— Lett the Meridians tell when I haue done. And the Equator be my startinge post to either Pole; The Paralells the Myles And Troppickes Stages for to passe the Clymes: If my plott hold; Sixe tymes Ile take my rest In either Hemispheare att soe many Sygnes And the degrees of eyghty shall not make Mee faint in my Intentions: Be propitious Y' Allternate Brothers to faire Tyndaris Through whose strong Mediation with the rough fac'd Kinge Oceanus I haue obtained Leaue to transport the Nations through the world Distinguisht by foure names to which Ile trye To add a fift part of discouerye Heere he starts att the Stage, discouers the Tobacco Smoake But heare mee thinkes I am Within some Strayghts With Magelan & Mayre nor Can a Bay discouer Yet there's a Smoake (nor is there Smoake 'thout fire) Which may proclaime the place Inhabbitted Though innaccessable, the waues ryde high Nor breake 'Lesse gainst the Rockes that under Lye All dangerous, yet difficultye bringes Greater Esteeme unto all Conquerings 4 Boyes in blacke stuffd Bellyed suttes Come Skippinge danncing the Anticke att which he Starts againe. My Resolution's lost 'twixt hope and feare What doe my Eyes discouer Walloweing here? The Storme forerunninge black-guard of the Seas (By me soe hight) by ffishers Porposes Tis Soe, I'le take in Cloth, dangers fore Spoake Like Serpents are when as their teeth are broake steps asyde

Second Entry Kinge Oceanus enters enrag'd attended by Balena and Physeter with other Sea Monsters for guardes and attendants—speakes Ocean: —What bold Attempter seekes to plumme my depth And make mee turne untill my Braines runne round Th'unconstant Goddesse must Commannd me still To shape my Ebbs and floweings to her prime Her wayne, her full, for humane wights must knowe Att their Commannds I doe nor Ebb nor flowe. turnes to them: Away Physeter fill your fountaine Skonce That cataract like it sinke whole fleetes att once And yow Balena that in strength excell Make all the deckes and keells change paralell The Porpos Boyes skip about him Whilest with my Little traine I rest Content To take some pastime in my Ellement Exeunt Phy: & Balen: He strikes the stage with a: Trident. ffrom neath which Come out two Trytons viserded— Sea weed on their heads & in Coats Sea greene, with shell trumpetts in their hands. Why Tritons howe? Come upp here awake the windes With your shell Trumpetts, Cause them t'make mee dannce Soe high and rough a Measure to their Ayre That I may seeme to quench the fiery Starrs Yet washe the Center of the Vniuerse. Lett them my Billowes (otherwise entire) Against the Rockes dash till they breake and rise In Cristall sparkes t'enrich the Cristall Skyes Leaueing to emblem out my wrath belowe An Angry foame: Then ffleeces of blacke Cloudes Swoln upp with Vapour; yet not ripe to fall In raine, soe darken all the Guides that Measure My Liquid plaine, that neuer more attempt Be made to ryde ore 't on a wooden horse Lett not the Sunne when he Comes to my Bed Draw ore 't a Crimson Curtaine nor beguilde The fragrant Morneing when from it he rises But by a weake and faint pale beame dispearse Abroad the Light from his Hydroppick boddy Nor Lett his Sister shine but through a Vale Yet such an Orient Tincture thence discouer Rubicunda flat: That euery wynde may sue to be her Louer. And spend the Lowdest of their breathes uppon her Lett all the Leauy Consort; with the Breach O'th'waters play att Checstone on the Beach Chime in a Storme: Nor Lett my dolphin tye himselfe in's Course to any Certaintye. But Cormorants begripe the Craggy shoare And Hearnes aboue the wayghtyer Cloudes shall Soare Whilest 'tis the Choughs delight to bath her selfe But I will Cast a feare uppon this Art That would discouer through mee euery part Blowe upp my boyes, I Long to stirre my Ioints The Tritons sound once and Nothinge appeares Againe, the windes doe sleepe and not remember The Halcyon dayes were ended with September They sound againe—And the Porposes rowle and tumble about Ocean: as he stands upp,—att Last the 4 Windes enter Bloweing And soe take their places att the 4 Corners of the Stage, their Instruments before mencioned—their habbitts Linnen girt to them—Perewiggs of Stareing haire—Iuye wreathes on their heads. Seaman from his Corner where he had stood embay'd It is noe short tyme sithence this Art the Pine ffirst taught to dannce uppon the swelling Brine O'th'Oceans Court, yet soe enrag'd before I neuer Sawe him: Well sithence this feauerish feare Shakes all my tackle Ile noe Longer staye his Menaces, nor soe prouoke my fate A Tempest doeth A Calme prognosticate Exit Naut: Ocean in Triumph Hee's gone, hee's gone, the tenth waue be his guide To Stix and Acheron, whilest wee Liue free Without Encroachments on our Libertye Turnes to the Musick which playes still Be still, be still, Our Nimble feete denye Our Leggs their rest unless yor harmonye Compos'd of Discords Cease Musicke ceases Your Will's obeyd Then Oceanus retireing to an Artificiall Rocke in forme of A Chaire which was plac'd Diametrically opposite to the Scæne, and on which was Raguaglio D'Oceano written in great Speakes againe to the Trytons as followes. Ocean: —Goe Trytons usher in my Sonnes that they May be instructed in their gouernments Exeunt Tritons att seuerall dores I heare that Pontus useth Violence Sometymes on Archipelag and the Iles When as fond Aquilo flatters his pride And ffretum's sullen and denyes to pay Lucina floud and Ebb. Synus alone Contented is, yeilding to eache their owne

Third Entry Fretum enters & after 3 Congies speakes As to my great undoubted Sire I Bowe And Bend the knees of my Obedience Your will most Royall father Oceanus: —Sonne, 'tis this: When first out of the Chaos I did runne And Compase in its part was Sollydder That Terra firma tooke for name whilest I Oceanus am Calld; wee both Like freinds Or Neighbour Princes (if a freind be not Too Lowe A style to Court a prince withall) Embrac't each other with such Mutuall Closes That you were borne my first and eldest Sonne And soe beare halfe your Mothers name of Terram Wherefore allthough some breaches haue produc't A full diuource betwixt us: yet my Charge Is that with due obedience you waft Her seruants to what port they shall designe Soe 't be within yor Bounds. ffor those againe I Charge yow not t'exceed. Yor portion falls In Vertues midle way, which is the best, Where for disports y' haue Candy Ile or Creet To entertaine yow; Malta for defence Where knights engarison'd keepe Residence If Cupids shafts Come piled from the forge Vulcane in Ætna keepes, faire Cicely Is wounded strayght and falls into yor Armes Sardinia and Corsica two twinns betroth themselues to yor soft Liquid Bed and Both Maiorca and Minorca think 't a Grace That yow'l be pleasd t'vouchsafe them an embrace. ffor wracks (as there must needes bee some to raise Your fame to those escape) in stead of Bayes The Leafe of Triumph, you an Ile possesse Affording Cypres fitt for Obsoqueis These Blessings yow enioy, then be Content fflowe not through pride, ebb not through discontent Fretum: As you Commannd soe must my waues obey There is noe striueing 'gainst a fathers Swaye

Fowrth Entry Pontus enters att ye same dore after A Tryton & Iossells Fretum in his retreat, speakes Brother I broke not this pruention Our father sent for me as well as yow And had not Helespont where Hero droun'd Detain'd mee to shed teares uppon his Tombe And my Arch Enemye Calld Pelagus (ffamous for yeilding to the Gretians Graues When Ilium's fate for Vengeance did pursue them) Layde Iland Rubbs to make me stumble att I had o're taine you Fretum: —Brother Lett noe storme Kindle 'twixt us Boyle upp our fathers wrath I left my Rodes to tell yow I was gone And durst not stay for A Companion Ocean: discovers the discord Is there A Tempest raisd betweene the Bayes And I sat here becalm'd awake yea windes And Scourge them for this ffolly. Tryton see Why Pontus Comes soe Slowly upp to mee Triton goes to them & after a Sylent passage of pacificacion. Comes in Maiesty up & speakes Pontus Sr your Commannds, the Euxine shore Lyes drye Till my returne againe to Trypoly. Ocean: —Loue to my Ofspringe might asswage mine Ire Kindled by your rough entrance and Soe fire Seeme to quench water but my Summons here 'Tis for your rough behauiour euery where Belike you thinke sithence Iason by your way Procur'd the Golden ffleece in Colchos Lay All Sea's but Siluer, Copper, Brasse or Mudd And you alone the Orient Goulden floud Be not mistaken for if you looke Backe You are not onely Great but Calld the Blacke Nor to exceed your Bounds, the Couenant's sett You are to Swallow none but Mahomett Pontus —Call mee what name you please, my power Confine To your Sole will, 't must answere my designe

Fiu't Entry Synus enters Ocean: —Stand by there with your Brother whilest I bid My Synus wellcome, there true Loue is spedd Where bosomes are to Like imboweled Thy presence is most milde, giue me a Kisse Incense my beard with the Aromatickes Of thy Choyce dewe, and Lett our Curld Lockes thus Leanes uppon him & huggs him Perfumed be with thy rich Calamus Yet wee must part; thou must retire; degrees Of Nature Enuye Such felicityes But ere thou goest, my blessing, Sacrifize Vnto thy shores a floud of Merchandize Synus —What thankefull Armes Bazora Lends shall pay Your Bountyes with Embracements euery day Ocean: —Obserue yr Charges then Sonns & be free Whilst I howld power ore Liquid Souranty Yet ere yea goe let Some kind waue express Your Duties to your Sire in Actiuenes Exeunt Fret: Pont: & Sinus. The 4 Windes play Soe they goe out in a dannce Blow vp yea winds, yet These youths gently moue That Tempests cease & All may end in Loue These gon out in a Short Dance ther Enters a Nayad or Nimph of ye Riuers in a Siluer waterd Kirtle & wast coat—a Chaplet of Glaiue or Sedg on her head & bull rushes in her hand adressing her Self humbly to Oceanus & Speaks

Sixt Entry Nayd —Great Sr Fair Cristallina yt's our Queen And ouer purling Springs & Cristall Streams Bears Sway alone Sends me her Nimph yt wayt Vpon those waters for to craue ye fauour of Her admittance to your presence Ocean —Lady Soe fayer request brought by So fayer a presence From one of So great Merit as yr Queen Cannot receiue deniall from my Throne But free access (for Once we were All one) Til Nature, finding yt ther might be cause To guiue ye Earth refreshment by Her lawes Opend ye Cauerns of ye Thirsty Ground To let my Liquor pass: but on Condition It should return again, & Soe it doth Bring in yr La. & She Shall haue Audience. Nayd —She hath preuented both; is come allredy

Seauenth Entry Cristallina enters & Speaks Think it not Strange (Great King) whose Sway extends As farr as Poles direct or Tropick bends That you Behould a Queen whose Powre's no more Than what ye Banks of Narrow Streams Enshore Sithence 'tis decreed that noe Condicion tyes The Greater not to Stoope, nor the Lesse to rise ffor though the world be round and those therein Like Lesser worlds appeare in euery thinge Soe that A Storme, A Calme, A Hill, A Dale May Emblem ffortune when shee fills A Sayle And when shee strikes it: yett it would imply ffarther in humors such Variety That Constancy should neuer turne Soe round A Bowle, wherin noe Byas Can be found Such Nature frames us, and her Lessons Crye downe all tasts, Seeke not Curiosytye Wherein you'r enuyed. And though Some Still stand Vncutt off by diuorce uppon the Land Here shee Bowes. And Iles; Yet they both Sue yow'le giue Accesse To their Ambassadours att my request Ocean: —'Tis Grannted, Call them in. Exit Trit:

Eight Entry Triton reenters—after whome Thamesis/Rhenus Ligeris/Tagus Tibris/Alpheus Cristal: —These from Europa Come—faire Thamesis Curld headed Rhenus, Liuely Ligeris Gould fingered Tagus, Tibers secrett waue Old Alpheus, where Diana's Nimphs wont Laue Indus, Ganges and Euphrates enter to whome shee points seuerally Niger & Nyle enter. Orenoke, parana, Maragnon enter These from Queene Asya are, Euphrates braue Great Ganges, Noble Indus of the East Those others there from Affrica are Sent As Sun-burnt Niger, and the fertile Nyle And those America presents to be her Messengers, as new found Orenoke Parana and Maragnon Skearce yet plum'd Now (Mighty Monarch) though through power yow sway Allmost all other Scepters, once obey And yeild unto these Orator s whoe runne Into yor Bosome for protection Gainst their Confinements, yet with this demannd (If you soe please) that either shore and Land ffrom whence they'r sent and where they'u beene embayd May for discouery finde your speciall Ayde. Oceanus raiseing upp himself Speakes. ffaire Nimph and Mistresse of the Cristall Springes As without Terra there were noe Such thinges Nor without homage Soe great power in Kinges Therefore whatsoere she Sends, and each here bringes I am Content t'accept for offerringes Ocean sitts downe againe Europe Then Thamesis Aduances, prsents the fleece of Wooll and Speakes Sr of undowbted power & unsearcht bound Whose Liquid farre stretch't Armes embrace the round And perfect Globe of the Earth: made Soe by them (ffor both togeather forme that Orient Gemm Or Pearle like Substance) whilest Like seedes disperst The Scattered Ilands ore your vniuerse Lye unregarded, daigne to cast your Eye Vppon one's present which for Soueraingtye Challenges right aboue them all and may Soe you afford it roome, and Poets way ffor if wee may beleeue them, Nature hurld it by, for to deuide it from the world Or rather t'sett 't appart there to beginne Some famous Storehouse or A Magazine How Pan and Leda doe Contend to blesse The Same: Here what I bringe speakes, & my dresse The Clearnesse of my Sisters streames Soe many Render Admired Soe Lustrous Bright-an-eye And that nor Guift nor habitt goe alone Th'white Rockes haue Styl'd it famous Albyon. Which Sithence Tyme-rypened Apprehension Seing it but a Corner o'th'Dominion Queene Europe Swayes & that its figures Stand Much Anguler, haue hight it Angle-Land Whence from though many goodly Riuers trye To Leese themselues to serue your Maiestye It was my fortune as their Misteresse (Knowne by the name of Bounteous Tamesis) To be employed as Cheife and here to shew The homage wee Acknowledge all to yow: Obedience Rowles me Ebbing to your throne Not now as earst for Transportation Of what on Cottsoll or on Lemster growe To Trafique in: Noe (Royall Patron) Knowe Europ Our Soueraigne seekes your fauour and Consent That all her Subiects, both of Continent And of the Iles, may with Like freedome Spend As Safety their Endeauours: to Extend Their Knowledge where the Secrett Southerne Pole Lockes upp what it from Natures use had Stole stands by Triton: after a whisper in Oceanus eare —Soyt fayct Comme ils desirent Rhenus Aduances, offers & speakes Great Prince whose vast Dominions doe Comprize Soe many thousand Lesser Scepteryes Vouchsafe a Calme Aspect on mee whoe Call Th'Helvetian Mountaines my Originall Out of whose pregnant Breasts I gush & shower On you the Tribute of an Emperour 'Sydes many petty Princes: All whoe Ioyne In this: you'le Soe farre Countenance their designe As to permitt they may Attempt and trye Within th'Antarticke Line discouerye stands by Duch / after ye Like Trit —Soyt ainsi Comme ils desirent Ligeris Comes upp, prsents, Speakes ffrom the Auuernian hills I runne in hast To Kisse those shores your Liquid plaine doeth Cast Into Amazement whilest noe Limmitts are Prescrib'd to bound the Syght from neere and farr Both doe Concurre as if for one Intent To dazell thoughts with Such a Wonderment My Suite then (Wonderous Sire) is in the name Of Gallia My Mistresse whence I came Shee Craues yow'le giue her Pylotts Leaue to Sound Those Southerne Bayes which yett were neuer found stands by Triton —Le Roy Le veult Tagus with Grauety aduances, presents, speakes Richest of Soueraignes whose depths doe Containe Treasures Like sands are Countlesse and whose Raigne Out measures Allmost all those Crittick Lines The fancy in the worlds distinction findes Knowe that Allthough from East to west I run And As Surueyor doe employ the Sunne To Mapp my ffortunes and both Indies gett To be the Scale where he doeth rise and Sett Yet from Castillyan Race deriu'd I would Not here desist, for all my Sandes are Gould But as I doe possesse great share in foure Parts of the Earth through my Enchanting Ore Soe that the fif't under Subiection fall Grannt Leaue to finde & me the Generall stands by Spanish Trit —C'est permis Comes up slowely, presents, speakes -Tybris —Lett not the Blasts of Arrogancy tent Your All orecomeing waues (as Incident To Soe Great powers) But with A Smileing Browe Add to your fame: Whose trumpett, Lett not Now Craue Acts of Ruine: Many Adore the Sunne But euery one will from A Tempest runne That Can I from faire Europes Garden Latium That old Saturnian Sanctuary am Come Where by the fauour of your offspringes soft And Gentle Terraine Ayre I am taught A Slower Measure, for without Controwle I Can my thoughts into his Brest unfold And though I water that delitious feild Abounds with such Variety and doeth yeild The horne of plenty, yett my pryde's hence growne I washe the Statelyest Cittye e're was Knowne Sythence Babells fall: And Least Confusions Iarre fforgotten be, my Waters troubled are: Shee in the Name o'th'rest would this Inferr Please yow t'giue way to her Aduenturer Into the South, And for what thence shee'le Carry Shee shall become your faithfull Tributary Trit. —è Concesso Old AlpheusAduances, presents and Speakes Staind in that Liuery tyme bestowes on all That Can record its Bountyes here I fall Into your presence, Leaueing of my Springes To Water still Achaias Blossominges That in the name of all those hills and Groaues The Sacred Alltars of Inspired Loues Arcadia flames with, shee be not denyde To wayt uppon the New-discouering Tyde Trit. Asia Indus aduances, presents & Speaks. Issude from Steep Imaus wombe & known By th'name of Indus I come to yr Throne To beg a boon: Cambaia & ye rest Of Territories bordring on ye East Decan & Malabar yt Coast ye Same Wher ye Mogol glories in his Great name Surat & Goa trade ports yt increase His Greatnes through their famed Marchandes Implore Your fauour; yt His Subiects may By Your good leau pass Noua Guinea And wher as yet Discouries haue not been They may adress themselus vnto yt Queen Triton as before Ganges aduances, presents & Speaks Deuiding India by my Stream soe Fam'd (Phison by Greeks) by Others Ganges nam'd I heer appeer; & from Bengala Throwe My Self at your feet, to whom we All doe owe Our Tributary Duties, pleas You thus To fauour then ye Sonn of Caucasus That Those high Lands I run from may find way T'accost yt Land is yet Incognita Tryton as before Euphrates aduances, Presents, Speaks Out of Mount Taurus Risen & in my way Passing along Mesopotamia I gaignd yt high prerogatiue to be One of Those waterd Edens nurcery (Or ye first Guarden I th'worlds Infancy) Then passing Babilon I did decline My course through Sinus Sway or Mesendine Vnto Ormus, & thence Bazora brings Euphrates to yr Court wt h's Offerings Both He & They Acceptance craue: & this Farther, yt Those by whom H' entrusted is As ye Prowd Perse, Rich Mede & theirs may be Admitted to Southern Discouery Tryton as before Affrica Nilus aduances wt h 9. armes, Speaks From Your Great Princes's Mountaines I come forth To pay vnto yr high Esteem & worth The Homage due; & into Fretum Slide (Your Eldest Sonn) Soe to be dignefide In my approaches: Nilus I relate To Prester Ihon yt Great worlds Potentate And passing Nubia doe on Egipts Coast Aduance nine Armes wherin my water's lost 'Less You recrent my Trauailes & Comply wt h Those Dominions yt 'thout me lay drye And t'Graunt free passage for ye Gipsy Crewe That pass ye Owld world ore to Seek a newe Tryton as before Niger aduances, presents, Speaks From ye Black Lake guaue me my name I Spring To offer Sacrefize vnto my King Oceanus: Large Niger thus proclaimes That all his drift's Obedience; & his aymes Nothing but Seruice to yt Powers desert Makes Him to leese him Self out at Cape Vert Only because those Regions I pass bye (wc h are not fewe) out of Curiosety Affect to make discoury wher as yet None o'th'worlds fowr parts a foot had Set You'l be propitious to yt Skill & Art wc h may Conduct them to th'yet vnknown part Triton as before America Orenoak aduances, presents, Speaks Fam'd Orenoak Slips by Guyanaes Shore To bring a present of yt Dazling Ore Her pregnant Mountaines are wt h child wt h: which The prowd Iberian Prouinces Enrich Passing by Trinidado too I bring A Sourain Plant to Cuer ye Oceans King Of Rhumes & of Catarrs, whose Vertues great Send warmth to Could, & Cooling vnto Heat Supply ye want of food, & in a word An Antedote t'Infectious Ayre afford Preuent Diseases of most kinds & are By Thores Art approued Singuler My Sute's but this, Guinanas Caribes May Sound those Southern vnknown passages Triton as before. Para or Rio de las Amazones presents, Speaks Gusht from ye Towring Mountains of Perüe Heer Para brings Their Treasury to You Lord of th'Atlantike Liquid world; & least The Lusitanians who clayme interest In these Dominions by discoury first Should be deny'd their Appetite & Thirst For more Discoury, Their Desire alon's For a Safe conduct for their Amazons To Seek & trye, wt yet vnknown, vnfound Remaines Conceald wt hin ye South-Pole-Ground Tryton as before Paraguay or Rio de la Plata presents, Speaks Heer from Ciania Paraguay is Sent The Greatest Riuer All yt Continent Containes whose Siluer Stream begot its Name Of Rio de la Plata, of whose Fame For Siluer Mines ye Spanyards being tould (who allwayes Thirst for Siluer & for Gould) Expected ther no less, than at my fall Their Caracks Should be Laden ther wt hall And yet not Satesfide I'm bid to Say Pleas you to Grant ye men of Paraguay Ciania Tucumania & ye rest Inhabit on my Banks Soe far t'be blest As to behould yt Queen & all her State The fowr parts of ye world Soe Emulate Tryton as before after a whisper wt h Oceanus

Ninth Entry Enter a Sett of Recorders & play Seuerall Dances to ye Seuerall Riuers who for Ioy of their happy Reception & Success Goe out Skipping & leaping in Figures answerable to ye Cuntrys They run from. Exeunt Flum: Cristallina: to Oceanus Sr, your benign Aspect towards my Subiects Makes Them to leese Themselus in Actiuenes Of Ioy-expressing-thanks: Nor fits it Me Defectiue in Acknowledgments to be For Soe Great fauours: wherfore I'le retire Muster vp all my Nayds or Nimphs to Gather Flowers to weaue into a Garland for you The Cowslip of ye mead, ye Spottles Lilly And to becalme yr waues ye Daffadilly Or else Narcissus whose hard fate it was To doat Soe much on His owne looking glass A Frend to rest & quiet: True Loues fancy The fowr-leaud Primrose, & ye Thoughtfull Pance, Roses & Eglantine They too Shall twine For to Incense ye Rest to wc h they ioyne And Violets in Souraign Purple dress To add more Fragrancy to All ye rest And when Their Skillfull fingers haue disposd them Into a Chaplet to adorn yr Browe I'le Send it to performe my thankfull Vowe. Exit: Cristal

Tenth Entry These gon out Reenters Balena, Phiseter & ye Tritons to whom Oceanus discouers his purpose of delusian. Ocean: Wellcome my Spells; now 'tis high time to bring My great Dessignes to Issue: He's noe King Nor worthy of yt Name, cannot dissemble These Bubbling Streams came Rowling to my presence I'le turn to Bubbles, Soe delude Their hopes Bring Those They'l Send vpon ye Coast to See A Glimmring of this Vnknown Maiesty Yet Close ye Scen again & Soe preserue Her Chastety Inuiolat for My Self If for reward She'l daign me worthy of Her. Tryton: Your Highnes Speaks most like yr Self, & if She Should proue Coy & Nice, & not rescent This Fauour from you, but refuse your bed She'l proue Ingrat, wc h Somms all can be Sayd. Ocean: 'Tis true at first all framd was for ye best Til Nature wanton fancied Nouelties And blew ye Mind vp to Ambitious Thoughts Of Coueting wt was aboue its reach Despising allwayes ye Condition present And Gaping after yt could not be had But I Shall fit These, bring Them to ye brink Of happines, then wt h dispair Them Sink For Their Presumptian, (Fortune ne're Soe lies As when Sh' Eggs on t'Impossebileties.) And thus I'le cause Such haightning Their desire By Shewing Them a Glims: yt Set on fier To haue fruition winds Shall fan ye Flame And Send Them packing home wise as they came Wherby They'l find their Error & Confess Ther's noe Such Cross as faigned happines

Eleuenth Entry [Ocean:] (Heer he discouers ye Sea-Man entring Th'Aduentrers Sure are not now far behind Sea Man enters Heer comes Tar-palin to bespeak a wind To waft Them; I'le draw in my former Rage Ang giue Him leau to Act on a Calme Stage Sea-Man: Speaks The Ayre Speaks fayre, ye Dappled Skie's Becheckerd wt h Little Lokes of wool portending Calmnes And All ye winds fast lockt vp in Their Denns Issue not forth t'awake Oceans fury Nor t'wrinkle more his Browe: Ile Set my Compass And Soe prepare for Steerage of These Gallants Vnto ye Inquisition of a New-world The Owld They Loath: (Soe nothing Man can find Saue Nouelty to Satiate his mind And guiue it rest:) Some of These craue ye North-Winds Fauour only, Others North North-East Noor & by West Ther are must haue & Some North East & by North All ye South to gain And t'win access to th'vnknown Souereign I'le rayse Those Starrs too by This Quadrants ayd Shall be their Guides vntil Dorado appeer And They pursue Her & forsake ye Bear

Twelf Entry Heer ye Seuerall Nations Enter in their Seuerall proper habits & Shields in their hands Whom ye Seaman presents in a few words to Oceanus Sea-Man Speaks again: Encouraged by Your High Gratious Answer Vnto Their Emissaries heer are Come The Seurall Nations both of Christendome And Other Parts to Clayme your Promise; Thus You'l make Them happy, your Self Glorious Ocean Let them approach; My Court like fier doth Shine And when bright Phebus casts a wanton eye Vpon my liquid plain it Sparkles mercy Much after yt of th'Other Element

Thirteenth Entry Heer whilst Each Nation makes his Obeisance & Soe comes vp to Oceanus presenting him Seuerally wt h their Shields wc h He deliuers to ye Trytons to howld for Him—Three Syrens of rare voyces to Theorbo & Lute are heard out of 3. Musike rooms aboue to Inuite by their ditties Terra Australis Incognita to vnuale & Soe discouer her Self & State wc h by degrees She doth, ye Trauerse beginning to be drawn Open very Slowly after ye Last Song— & then closing vp again as Slowly Out of Each windowe ye names of ye 3. Syrens hanging out in Great Letters viz: Parthenope Ligea & Leucosia: First Song by Parthenope Vnuale vnuale Chast Queen Lock vp noe more Thy Bewty & Thy Store But to ye Other parts o'th'World be Seen That come therfore And wt h Ambitious Eye Fraight for Discouery Approach your Coast Dain Them yt Fauour else their Labour's Lost Second Song by Ligea Appeer, appeer Bright Southern Princess Royall To Those will noe Deniall But Come here Aduentrers Bowld To behowld What by Coniectral Art The Gloabs to Them impart That yr Dominions ends Soe far Extend As yt ther's yet vnfathomd & vntould A New World half as large as is ye Owld Third Song by Leucosia Shew thy Self & graunt access To Thy Throne Great Misteress Of yt world is yet Vnknown Open a Port To Their Resort Who through ye Fauour of ye Seas Seek to find out New Passages And let Their fayr Endeauours find To Satiate ye Minds Of those Employd Them Soe much Grace As to Behould your Face wc h done They Shall be gon Retire again And what was promisd from ye Mayn Being Ratefide Perish & Sinke in Their Presumptions Tide Heer ye Trauerse Opens & Terra Australis discouers Her Self on her Throne in ye Scene & then it drawes closs & Shuts vp again Oceanus: Speaks As my Decrees, Soe are my Promises The Medes & Persians to mine goe less Soe hauing Shown These boasters what They Craue To See, though not enioy: noe more I haue To doe wt h Them or Theirs, but to Bestowe The Lowdest Breath my Notus heer can blow Wt h his Assotiats on them: & Soe will I Strut out Their Sayles, till They fall fould on Sylla Seeking to Shun Caribdis homwards bound (For in Presumption Dainger's allwayes found) Breath out my winds: & for Their forlorn chance Let Auster weep a Showr, Eol aduance His moystned wing, & All in Ayre express The Fate is incident & ill Success To Those rest not contented wt h their owne But Rashly Seek for more wt h Phaeton Plunge Them into ye deeps, & let Them knowe What vnto me is right, & what They owe Yet ere They goe Some Lofty Galliard Shewe Their Thankfullnes, & what to Me was due Heer as if Enchanted by ye Lowd Musiks high Strain They All fall into a Morrice & Mad Iomping Phantastike Daunce & Soe depart ye Seaman after them Exeunt: They gon Oceanus inuoaks Oryon Ocean: Come forth Oryon bright & Cleer Nor more affright ye Passenger On my Curld waues, ye Tempest's ore And I Thy Harp-Strings now Implore To Court My Mistres wt h & t'be Wittnes to This Solemnety

Fowerteenth Entry Heer Enters Oryon riding vpon a Dolphin trapt wt h Flower de Luces playing vpon an harp Studded wt h Starrs &c: At wc h as he approaches ye Trauerse is drawn open & ye Scene appeers at large—From neath wc h as out of a Caue comes Orpheus plaijng likewise vpon an Harp an Antike Dance wc h is performed By Two like Beasts, two like Rocks of Ston & two like Trees who followed him out, wc h ended quickly Oceanus Licences ye Six Reuelers to depart: Ocean: —Retire Retire After Euridoce Retire Abuse noe more ye Vestall fire By yr fond Meteors: Get ye Hence Torture noe more Her Patience Is All perfection Chast & Bright Rurall Strains may Her affright As if Those Trauailers late heer Were Come again t'attempt Her Sphere: Exeunt Beasts, Rocks, Trees

Fiueteenth Entry Now Orpheus Consorting wt h Oryon They play together a Madrigall or Some Solemn graue Tune to wc h ye Princes descends Maiestically out of ye Scene wt h her attendants of Six Yong Princes & Six La s: Of Honer She presenting her Self to Oceanus in acknowledgment of his Fauour yt had Protected Her Chastety from ye Late attempters to invade it Terra Austral: Speaks. 'Tis not th'inchanted Ayre from Strings well toucht Voyces well Ordred, yt Compells me t'leau Those Sacred Mansions (wher noe foot ere trod But mine & of my Subiects) to descend And Grace your watry Orbs (Great King of waues) But in acknowledgement of yt Protection You lately did afford when Violence Attempted was T'accost my Virgin Pallace By Some whose wandring minds vnsatesfide (Though ye whol world besides was Theirs) endeauourd A Rape vnto my Throne, til You dismist Them And Sent Them back by Nereus Tethyos Sonn To Court His Daughter Thetis:—For wc h good My Kingdome must pay Tribute to your Flood. Oceanus Answers: Sole Empres of ye Vnknown world, & thus An Enuy to ye Rest Inhabited By Men as Seuerall minded as their fashions Stil Coueting Some New Discoueries (When All my Passages Secret containes) (Arcano del mare Whither in Search of Riches or of Fame Or Both I Spare to tel: yet when I had brought Them to behould a Glance of your bright Ray Which Shut again vnder Nubecula I tost Them home Skearce Satesfide, & ther Leau most of Them to Steer by ye North Bear I craue noe other Salery for This But yt I Stil haue leau yr Shores to kiss And as my Comfort to Embrace yr Throne And Guard it from invasion as my Owne And t'loose ye Bow-knot of yr Virgin Zone Princess: 'Tis Graunted—bless These Twinklers on each Side That wayt on me & then I'le be your Bride Ocean: Tryton Sound Thrice, Proclaym this happy hower Ther's naught now I deny wt hin my power turns to ye Princes Enlargd by Your fayer Graunt, & to Express The ioyfull Tidings of Such happines Let Orpheus & Oryon Sute a Strain May Captiuate ye footings of Your Train And Cast them into Figures Such as ne're Were known before in any Other Sphere Heer Orpheus & Oryon Play ye Mayn Masking Daunce wc h ye Six Yong Princes & Six Ladies attired in Starrs performe in a New composed figure —wc h ended They wayt vpon Their Princes vp into ye Scene again And Oceanus follows: yet before He goes he Sends abroad ye Seuerall Escuttchions to ye Principall of ye Spectators as Trophies of his Poletike fallacy & Speaks— Ocean: to ye Tryton Carry as Trophies of my Power & Sway Their Scuttchions who through Me did Seek a way T'haue made my Vn-toucht Misteress Their Praye And tel th'Spectators 'tis e're I goe hence My Care thus to reward Their Patience Soe Oceanus Goes vp into ye Scene after ye Princes & her Constellations & then ye Trauers draws closs vp again & all is done: only a Chorus of Mer-Men & Mer-Mayds come forth wt h Spunges, Currall, Sea weed, Combs made of Fish bones & Looking-glasses & conclude all in Three Epilogues morall

The first performd by ye Fiue Sences 1: Epilogue (1) Audit: Now let ye Spheres Contend Wc h to our Ears More Melody Commend For good Yet Soe distinctly play We may Wt h Ease distinguish of their mood And Key Whither to flat or Sharp The Tunes are Set Command Oryons Harpe And not to break The Consort Noats May from Diuining Sybells Throats Or Syrens Speak Such Rauishments as may create All wondering Yet Let vs heer too (neer her Fate) Fair Leda Sing. (2) Vis: Let not ye Glaring Sun-beams light Hinder vs ye Content (Allthough at Mid-days hower When Those haue trebble power) Of counting euery Starr ye Night— Monopolizing Element Seeks to engross, nor let ye Center keep Our Eyes from following Phebus through ye deep (3) Gust: Fil me a sip Of Aganippe And ye Nectarian Ieuce Produce More wonder to my Pallat When tasted after an Ambrosean Sallet (4) Olfa: 'Tis not ye Cost & worth Of Seuerall Perfumes The pregnant Earth brings forth In Couslip Violet & Rose Or Spatious Sea assumes To be her Lees The Amber grees Nor wt ye Ciuets in their baggs inclose But yt this Sence wt h th'others Bear true parts Purchase a breath yt Smothers Not from a Dampe: but from two Louers harts. (5) [Tact:] Graunt an Embrace Of a Sun-beame Or Shaddowes gloomy Leam And for to Trace A Bird yt Cutts ye wind Or Sayling Ship yt leaus noe Track behind

2. Epilogue (1) Goe hunt ye Ocean For Venison And Let ye Land Be draggd For Oysters may present Both Raggd And Orient Pearle, to Iewell & delight Our Various Appetite Then bid ye Ayrs Commander Produce ye Salamander Whilst Soaring higher Camelions Seek to Change their food to Fier (2) This done return & let me knowe Wher Flames are Could And Snow Doth burne Wher Leaus hatch into fowle And Beasts like Plants doe growe (3) When Fields Are ploughd wt h Keeles And lusty Goulden Ears of Corne All waters crowne Then may be Sought & found The Pretious Vnicorn And Phenixes Not Soe confind Vnto Their Cinder-kind But making wonder less Couple & payer Lik t'other minstrells of ye Ayer So Procreate ye while Some dream 'tis from their funerall Pile (4) All this & more though we would find And See Yet can In noe wise Reach Impossebileties Confess we must ye Mind of Man Insatiat Thinks only that It wanteth rare & Great All else of lowe Esteem & Counterfaict.

3. Epilogue All Things at first were Soe dispos'd Some for to be Conceald, Others Disclosd For Soe ye God of Nature did deuise T'appeer in Open works, & Misteries Who for to kindle more desire in Her Commands a knee heer, ther a whol wonderer Nor euer can She grow soe Owld to be Full Satesfide wt h Longd for Nouelty But Like ye Serpent Stript doth Stil pursue All Curious Thoughts & Fancies to renewe And whilst Her Timbring is to grow more wise She's all Inflam'd a Phenix Sacrefize Vntil an Other Bird-like-wish as rare Fledg from those Ashes claime in Her a Share Soe Endless is yt minde we heer posess In hauing All yet iudging nothing less For as those Bounties we receiue Should rayse Our Soules not more to Couet, but to prayse For wt we know allredy: So 'twer good 'Fore we Sought more Our Selus we vnderstood: But like Abortiue Issues So we can Ingender in Conceipt it Makes ye Man And He yt doth not vndertake to know More than He doth had better not 'been So Thus doth our Parent's weeny danlings then Seem to Instruct vs Her true Children 'Til wt h our bubble Dispositians plaijng At last we find we work our owne betraijng And whilst beyond our Span we Seek to Strayn 'Tis but a Pin or Counter is ye gain. Ambition, Pride, & Auarice contend To Swallow All our Contemplations lend And what Somere we ayme to bring to pass Good or bad Fortune proues its Looking-glass Soe yt if we would place our dressings true We Should look first what's likely to ensue And then attempt noe more but yt wc h lies Within ye Fathom of our proper Sise But wrought vp into Tempest by those winds Our Mother Serues our Dispositian finds Noe rest til It hath tride by Sea & Land What Soeuer It desires to bring to hand And when both Seas & Lands haue compast been Ther's Some thing Stil Vnfound, Some thing Vnseen Basta.
? Mensuraque fictis Crescit & auditis aliquod Nouus adijcit auctor. Metamor—
